page.title: Trials and judicial hearings following the 2011 Egyptian revolution

rev.diff:
Line 2: Line 2:
The '''trials and judicial hearings following the [[2011 Egyptian Revolution]]''' were a series of legal moves to establish accountability among the various [[Egypt]]ian government officials and prominent businessmen.
The '''trials and judicial hearings following the [[2011 Egyptian Revolution]]''' were a series of legal moves to establish accountability among the various [[Egypt]]ian government officials and prominent businessmen.
â
A series of arrests and travel bans was imposed on high profile figures following the ousting of the former president [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s regime. These were based on several charges: causing the death of as many as 800 demonstrators;<ref name="Detention">{{cite web|author=|url= http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/14/world/middleeast/14egypt.html?_r=1 |title= Prosecutors Order Mubarak and Sons Held |work=The New York Times |date=13 March 2011|accessdate=13 April 2011}}</ref> the injury of around 5,000 demonstrators; as well as [[embezzlement]], [[profiteering]], [[money laundering]] and [[human rights abuses]]. Notable figures arrested included Mubarak, his wife [[Suzanne Mubarak|Suzanne]], his sons [[Gamal Mubarak|Gamal]] and [[Alaa Mubarak|Alaa]], former Interior Minister [[Habib el-Adly]], former Housing Minister [[Ahmed El Maghrabi]], former Tourism Minister [[Zoheir Garana]], and the former secretary of the National Democratic Party for Organisational Affairs [[Ahmed Ezz]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1036/eg31.htm |title=Al-Ahram Weekly | Egypt | How the mighty have fallen |publisher=Weekly.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-02-02 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Arrest warrants were also issued for some public figures who had already left the country during the start of the revolution, mostly on charges of financial misappropriations. These included the former minster of trade and industry, [[Rachid Mohamed Rachid]], and Hussein Salem, a business tycoon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000619367&fid=1725 |title=Hussein Salem caught in Dubai with $500m |publisher=Globes |date=2011-01-31 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
+
A series of arrests and travel bans was imposed on high profile figures following the ousting of the former president [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s regime. These were based on several charges: causing the death of as many as 800 demonstrators;<ref name="Detention">{{cite web|author=|url= http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/14/world/middleeast/14egypt.html?_r=1 |title= Prosecutors Order Mubarak and Sons Held |work=The New York Times |date=13 March 2011|accessdate=13 April 2011}}</ref> the injury of around 5,000 demonstrators; as well as [[embezzlement]], [[profiteering]], [[money laundering]] and [[human rights abuses]]. Notable figures arrested included Mubarak, his wife [[Suzanne Mubarak|Suzanne]], his sons [[Gamal Mubarak|Gamal]] and [[Alaa Mubarak|Alaa]], former Interior Minister [[Habib el-Adly]], former Housing Minister [[Ahmed El Maghrabi]], former Tourism Minister [[Zoheir Garana]], and the former secretary of the National Democratic Party for Organisational Affairs [[Ahmed Ezz]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1036/eg31.htm |title=Al-Ahram Weekly | Egypt | How the mighty have fallen |publisher=Weekly.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-02-02 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Arrest warrants were also issued for some public figures who had already left the country during the start of the revolution, mostly on charges of financial misappropriations. These included the former minster of trade and industry, [[Rachid Mohamed Rachid]], and [[Hussein Salem]], a business tycoon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000619367&fid=1725 |title=Hussein Salem caught in Dubai with $500m |publisher=Globes |date=2011-01-31 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
Mubarak's ousting was followed by widespread allegations of corruption against numerous other government officials and senior politicians.<ref>{{cite news|author=Phillip Inman |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/04/hosni-mubarak-family-fortune |title=Mubarak family fortune could reach $70bn, say experts | World news | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= 2011-02-04|accessdate=2011-03-23 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Mahmoud Muslim |url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289811&IssueID=2068 |title=Mostafa Al Fiqi: a big personality in the presidency confirmed that Â«MubarakÂ» will not run and his son would be the alternative |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> These included the former speaker of the Egyptian Parliament, [[Fathi Sorour]], and the former speaker of the higher legislative body ([[Shura Council]]), [[Safwat El Sherif]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/6644/Egypt/Politics-/NDP-fires-Mubarak--then-what.aspx |title=NDP fires Mubarak â then what? - Politics â Egypt â Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-02-28 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/news/Egypt/Politics/2011/March/6/elshrief_announcement.aspx |title=Ø§ÙØ´Ø±ÙÙ ÙÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØªÙØ§ÙÙ Ø­Ø³Ø§Ø¨Ø§Øª Ø®Ø§ØµØ© Ø®Ø§Ø±Ø¬ ÙØµØ± |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=2011-03-06 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Trials of the accused officials started on March 5, 2011, when the former interior minster of Egypt, [[Habib el-Adli]], appeared before the Giza Criminal Court in Cairo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/february/27/adly_judgment.aspx |title=5 ÙØ§Ø±Ø³.. Ø¨Ø¯Ø¡ ÙØ­Ø§ÙÙØ© Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ø¯ÙÙ Ø£ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§ÙØ§Øª |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=2011-02-27 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> The trials of el-Adli and other public figures are expected to take a long time.
Mubarak's ousting was followed by widespread allegations of corruption against numerous other government officials and senior politicians.<ref>{{cite news|author=Phillip Inman |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/04/hosni-mubarak-family-fortune |title=Mubarak family fortune could reach $70bn, say experts | World news | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= 2011-02-04|accessdate=2011-03-23 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Mahmoud Muslim |url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289811&IssueID=2068 |title=Mostafa Al Fiqi: a big personality in the presidency confirmed that Â«MubarakÂ» will not run and his son would be the alternative |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> These included the former speaker of the Egyptian Parliament, [[Fathi Sorour]], and the former speaker of the higher legislative body ([[Shura Council]]), [[Safwat El Sherif]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/6644/Egypt/Politics-/NDP-fires-Mubarak--then-what.aspx |title=NDP fires Mubarak â then what? - Politics â Egypt â Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-02-28 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/news/Egypt/Politics/2011/March/6/elshrief_announcement.aspx |title=Ø§ÙØ´Ø±ÙÙ ÙÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØªÙØ§ÙÙ Ø­Ø³Ø§Ø¨Ø§Øª Ø®Ø§ØµØ© Ø®Ø§Ø±Ø¬ ÙØµØ± |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=2011-03-06 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Trials of the accused officials started on March 5, 2011, when the former interior minster of Egypt, [[Habib el-Adli]], appeared before the Giza Criminal Court in Cairo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/february/27/adly_judgment.aspx |title=5 ÙØ§Ø±Ø³.. Ø¨Ø¯Ø¡ ÙØ­Ø§ÙÙØ© Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ø¯ÙÙ Ø£ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§ÙØ§Øª |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=2011-02-27 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> The trials of el-Adli and other public figures are expected to take a long time.
